prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with 2 spectral windows with a bandwidth of 468 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 8 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. The three spectral windows have been set to cover three different OH+ lines, that are redshifted into band 6. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
The H2O+ flux density for SDP.17b is approximated assuming the H2O/H2O+ flux ratio would be close to that of Mrk 231. Therefore we expect the H2O+ lines to be 2-3 times weaker than the detected H2O line which has a flux density of 29 mJy. By going down to a 2 mJy sensitivity we expect to detect the H2O+ lines with a SNR of 5.

We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with a single spectral window with a bandwidth of 234 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 16 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. This spectral window has been set to cover the CH line, that is redshifted into band 4. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
Expected CH flux density for is calculated by using the various detections in both Arp 220 and Mrk 231. The H2O(3_{30}-3_{21})/CH ratio in Arp 220 is in the order of unity. Eventhough CH has not been detected in Mrk 231, since it was not in the observed range of frequency, we expect the H2O(3_{30}-3_{21})/CH ratio would be close to that of the similar ULIRG Arp 220, e.g close to unity. Therefore, instead of using CO(7-6)/CH we use the ratio CO(7-6)/H2O(3_{30}-3_{21}) which is approximately 2 in Mrk 231. The approximated CH flux results in being half of the CO(7-6) flux in RX J0911.4+0551, thus, we expect a 5 rms detection of CH in RX J0911.4+0551 by going down to 4 mJy sensitivities.

We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with 3 spectral windows with a bandwidth of 468 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 4 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. The three spectral windows have been set to cover three different OH+ lines, that are redshifted into band 6. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
The expected flux density of OH+ is approximated by using the H2O/OH+ flux ratio in Mrk 231 which is around 2-3. In the case of SDP.17b, detected H2O flux density is 29 mJy. Therefore going down to 2 mJy sensitivities will allow us to detect OH+ with an SNR of 5.

We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with a single spectral window with a bandwidth of 234 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 16 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. This spectral window has been set to cover the CH line, that is redshifted into band 4. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
Expected CH flux density for SDP.17b is calculated from the spectra of Arp 220 by assuming the CH/H2O flux density ratio of 2 would be the same for SDP.17b. Considering the 29 mJy of H2O flux density in for this source, we expect the 12 rms detection of CH by going down to a 5 mJy sensitivity.

We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with 2 spectral windows with a bandwidth of 468 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 8 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. The three spectral windows have been set to cover three different H2O+ lines, that are redshifted into band 7. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
The CO/H2O+ flux density ratio in Mrk 231 is found to be around 2-3. Assuming that the corresponding ratio will be close to that of the Mrk 231 in RX J0911.4+0551, we expect to detect an H2O+ flux density of around 10 mJy. By going down to a 2 mJy sensitivity we will have a SNR of 5.

We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, with the 12-m Array. We expect point-like sources, thus we do not need to worry about extended structures.
We have chosen a correlator setup with 2 spectral windows with a bandwidth of 468 MHz, and applying an spectral average of 8 to reach a final spectral resolution of around 2 km/s. The three spectral windows have been set to cover three different H2O+ lines, that are redshifted into band 7. The total bandiwdth will be around 500 km/s, necessary since these sources are associated with broad line widths, of up to a few hundreds km/s. The spectral resolution of 2 km/s will permit to study the different line shapes in detail.
The H2O+ flux density for SDP.17b is approximated assuming the H2O/H2O+ flux ratio would be close to that of Mrk 231. Therefore we expect the H2O+ lines to be 2-3 times weaker than the detected H2O line which has a flux density of 29 mJy. By going down to a 2 mJy sensitivity we expect to detect the H2O+ lines with a SNR of 5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The goal of this proposal is to derive the ISM composition in conjunction with the ionization rates in two selected high-redshift sources using molecular species OH+, H2O+ and CH. The detection of light hydrides OH+ and H2O+ in our own Galaxy and in the local Universe has subtantiated that these species are robust tools to characterize the ISM properties, yet they have not been detected in high-redshift galaxies due to the lack of sensitivity of the current observations. We propose to observe two sources that represent the two dominant galaxy populations in the high-redshift Universe: submillimeter galaxies and AGN-hosts, where these lines of interest are shifted to ALMA bands. We stress that the species OH+ and H2O+ are powerful probes of the molecular-atomic transition zones with their abundance ratio probing the molecular fraction of the gas. We aim to: (1) use CH lines to derive the total molecular hydrogen abundance, (2) use the OH+/H2O+ ratio and derived H2 abundance to retrieve the HI abundances, (3) use OH+/HI ratio to deduce ionization rates for the two selected galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
